items.title: Characterization of geothermal resources and estimation of power potential of Badrinath geothermal field northwest Himalaya India
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 09 October 2025

Characterization of geothermal resources and estimation of power potential of Badrinath geothermal field northwest Himalaya India
                    Sameer K. Tiwari1, √Årni Ragnarsson2 & Gudni Axelsson3

Scientific Reports

volume¬†15, Article¬†number:¬†35291 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate-change impactsEnergyEnvironmental impact

AbstractGeothermal energy is a recognized renewable resource in the present scenario, with over 30 nations generating electricity and 88 using it for heating and heat pumps. Despite its substantial geothermal potential, India has yet to develop this resource because of limited geological exploration, reservoir characterization, and technological constraints. The Indian Himalayas host over 300 geothermal fields, offering a promising avenue for sustainable energy deployment in remote regions. This study evaluates the geothermal potential of the Badrinath geothermal field in the northwest Himalayas using a volumetric heat estimation method integrated with Monte Carlo simulations, addressing uncertainties in subsurface temperature distribution, heat capacity, and fluid recharge. Results indicate a maximum thermal power potential of 39 MWt and an electrical generation potential of 3.0 MWe, demonstrating its viability for small-scale power production. Furthermore, the design of a district heating system for the guesthouse is investigated, with particular attention to optimizing thermal energy transfer efficiency from the geothermal spring to the radiators. Despite extreme winter temperatures reaching ‚àí‚Äâ10¬†¬∞C, our findings confirm that geothermal water can be effectively utilized for heating applications without endangering the structural integrity of heat exchangers and distribution pipelines. This study represents the first systematic assessment of the Badrinath geothermal field, providing insights for future geothermal energy utilization in the Indian Himalayas.

IntroductionThe transition to a carbon-free society depends on the prompt adoption of renewable energy sources (RES) to replace fossil fuels1. While wind and solar energy are cost-competitive, their intermittency limits their capacity to provide reliable baseload power2. Geothermal energy (GTE) emerges as a strong candidate, providing the reliability needed for a sustainable energy future2. Geothermal energy cuts greenhouse gas emissions, supporting United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) goals, and is a sustainable and eco-friendly source3,4. Geothermal energy offers a distinct advantage over other renewable sources because it provides baseload electricity and enables direct utilization5.These unique characteristics have contributed to a significant global increase in geothermal electricity generation and direct applications over the past few decades6,7,8. Geothermal systems are primarily formed because of exothermally heated groundwater driven by convection through fractures, high geothermal gradients, and heat sources such as active tectonic zones (e.g., the Himalayas), volcanic regions, radioactive decay in the Earth‚Äôs crust, plate boundaries (continental or divergent), and sedimentary basins9,10,11,12,13,14. India ranks first in energy consumption among developing nations15, and the financial burden of importing fossil fuels has become increasingly unsustainable16. Given the global urgency to address climate change and reduce fossil fuel dependency, the international community is rapidly transitioning to cleaner energy alternatives.The geothermal potential of the Himalayan region, particularly the Garhwal Himalaya, is closely associated with the Main Central Thrust (MCT), which functions as a deep-seated regional heat source9,11,17,18,19. This tectonic structure enables meteoric water to infiltrate to considerable depths, where it is heated and subsequently re-emerges as geothermal activity19. In the study area, geothermal manifestations result from convective water movement in the upper crust within a confined zone, where heat is transferred from the source to the surface under free-surface conditions8,20,21. The structural setup extends approximately 150¬†km northwest, hosting multiple geothermal resources19,22. These observations are consistent with the high heat-flow anomalies recorded along the MCT in the Garhwal Himalaya, which are associated with numerous hot springs and geothermal fields occurrences11,22.During electricity production, hot water gradually releases its heat, leading to a progressive decline in temperature6. However, the remaining thermal energy can be harnessed for various purposes, such as geothermal cooling, greenhouse farming, space heating, snow melting, geothermal heat pumps, district heating, industrial applications, gas and mineral extraction, and balneotherapy (e.g., lagoon tourism and spa facilities) through a cascade utilization approach. Geothermal resource assessment integrates surface manifestation observations with geoscientific data, including geophysical, geochemical, and geological analyses, to evaluate such potential23.Geothermal resource assessment techniques can be classified into four primary categories: (1) surface thermal flux, (2) volume, (3) planar fracture, and (4) magmatic heat budget. The volume method proves particularly effective due to its broad applicability, the capacity to accurately measure or estimate parameters, manageable error assessment, and the potential to address uncertainties related to recoverability and recharge through future modeling and engineering techniques24. This approach enhances the reliability of geothermal assessments and facilitates sustainable resource management.Estimating geothermal reservoir resources is primarily based on stored heat and volumetric methods, with Monte Carlo simulation widely regarded as the most reliable resource estimation25. The volumetric method evaluates the thermal energy of the system by treating the reservoir as a unified body or dividing it into layers and smaller blocks, each assigned unique values for essential parameters. Key parameters include temperature, porosity, area, thickness, density, and the heat capacity of the fluid and rock matrix26. By applying Monte Carlo simulation, uncertainties in these parameters can be quantified, resulting in more accurate and dependable estimates27. This integration of probabilistic modeling enhances the reliability of resource evaluation and improves decision-making in geothermal energy development.The Monte Carlo method demonstrates how randomness can inform decisions in the face of uncertainty. By repeatedly simulating outcomes for unknown variables, it generates statistically robust results through numerous iterations. For example, rolling a die produces possible outcomes ranging from 1 to 6, but the exact result remains unpredictable, highlighting the role of chance. Similarly, geothermal reservoir parameters such as area, thickness, porosity, and temperature also exist within a range of possible values, each carrying inherent uncertainty27.To achieve accurate results, these uncertainties are modeled using suitable probability distributions (e.g., normal, triangular, uniform, or log-normal) based on the specific characteristics of the geothermal field under investigation. The simulation then generates many random values for each parameter, which are processed iteratively until the results converge into a reliable estimate28. By combining sampling theory with numerical analysis, Monte Carlo simulation has evolved into a powerful tool in computational science, enabling detailed quantification of complex geothermal systems with high precision29.The widespread adoption of Monte Carlo Simulation (MCS) in geothermal research is primarily because of advancements in computing, which enable complex simulations that were previously labor-intensive30,31. This approach allows known geothermal resource characteristics to be projected into potential distributions within the same area30,32. A similar approach, the volumetric heat-in-place method, was initially developed by the United States Geological Survey (USGS)24,33 and later refined by34,35,36.In this study, the volumetric heat-in-place method is combined with Monte Carlo simulation to evaluate uncertainties in estimating the geothermal power potential of the Badrinath geothermal field in the Garhwal Himalaya, India. The assessment incorporates surface manifestations, geochemical and geophysical analyses, geological surveys, and dissolved silica thermometry data. The findings indicate a substantial geothermal potential, suggesting that Badrinath is well-suited for developing a pilot geothermal heating system to meet local energy demands.Geological setup, data, and methodsStudy areaRegions with high geothermal gradients, such as tectonically active areas or plate boundaries, commonly display geothermal anomalies13,19,21,37,38. A geothermal system consists of three key components: a heat source, a reservoir, and a transfer medium, usually a fluid that transports heat to the surface39,40. In India, notable geothermal regions are found in the Himalayas, primarily in deeply incised river valleys and along major geological structures, including the Indus-Tsangpo Suture Zone (ITSZ) and Main Central Thrust (MCT)19. The rapid uplift and erosion of the Himalayan range have resulted in a steep geothermal gradient, mainly driven by hydrothermal activity41,42. Magnetotelluric surveys in the Garhwal region of the northwest Himalayas have identified low-resistivity layers at an average depth of 5 kilometers22. Across India, approximately 300 geothermal springs or fields have been identified, with nearly half (about 120) located in the Himalayan region13,19,37,38.The ITSZ defines the northern boundary of the Himalayan orogeny, while the Himalayan Frontal Thrust (HFT) marks its southern limit43. This region is divided into four primary litho-tectonic units, separated by south-dipping intercontinental thrusts, including the South Tibet Detachment (STD), (MCT), and the Main Boundary Thrust (MBT)44. Notable geothermal activity in the Garhwal Himalaya is concentrated around the MCT zone, which is characterized by high heat flow (130‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ30 mW/m2) and steep temperature gradients (60¬∞‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ20¬†¬∞C/km) in the northwest Himalaya45. In the Alaknanda Valley, geothermal features are associated with rock types such as gneiss, schist, and quartzite, all belonging to the Central Himalayan Crystallines46. This site contains gneiss, schist interbedded with calc-silicate, calc-schist, marble, and quartzite, all part of the central crystalline group47. The rocks exhibit asymmetrical folding, forming anticlines and synclines (Fig.¬†1).Fig. 1Study area with the location of the Badrinath geothermal field (modified after Tiwari et al.19).Full size imageThe Garhwal region of the northwest Himalayas is influenced by the Indian summer monsoon (I.S.M.) and westerly winds, which impact the rivers and streams in the area. The two major proglacial tributaries of the Ganga River system, Alaknanda and Bhagirathi, drain an area of approximately 30,000 km2.Badrinath is home to a single geothermal spring, strategically located on the right bank of the Alaknanda River at a remarkable elevation of 3089¬†m above sea level. This spring emerges from morainic deposits and is elegantly enclosed by a dome-like structure, along with other permanent installations37. The water, consistently heated to 55.6¬†¬∞C, flows into various Kunds, serving as a vital resource for pilgrims. It is characteristically tasteless, possesses a distinct sulfurous odor, and occasionally contains gas bubbles, adding to its unique appeal. With an impressive flow rate of approximately 400 L per minute19, this spring not only fulfills spiritual needs but also showcases striking geological features, including visible carbonate deposits near the Tapta Kund, while displaying no ferruginous staining (Fig.¬†1). Located just 50¬†m downstream, a second spring with a gentle temperature of 20¬†¬∞C offers its unique attributes. Its exact origin remains unclear, obscured by surrounding permanent structures. This colorless, slightly sour water is used for practical purposes such as bathing and laundry, with a notable discharge rate of around 190 L per minute. Collectively, these springs enhance Badrinath‚Äôs spiritual significance and highlight the region‚Äôs fascinating natural phenomena. About 50¬†m downstream, a lukewarm spring with a temperature of 20¬†¬∞C also exists. Its precise origin is unclear due to surrounding permanent structures. The water is colorless, slightly sour, and used for bathing and laundry, with a discharge rate of approximately 190 L per minute.The study area has a cold-temperate climate, with snowfall occurring in the upper valleys during December and January, leading to the emergence of springs19,48,49. The study area lies within the inner Himalayan Range, characterized by rugged terrain with steep hills and deep valleys, with elevations ranging from 1400 to 6596¬†m above sea level. The region has a cold-temperate climate, and snowfall occurs in the upper reaches of the valleys during December and January. The monsoon season, spanning June to September, brings the heaviest rainfall, with an annual average of 1000¬†mm and 1200 mm48. Additionally, the region is considered highly promising for geothermal energy exploration37.The primary objective of geothermal resource assessments is to determine geothermal resources‚Äô long-term power generation potential while ensuring sustainable utilization for at least 50¬†years. Accordingly, resource management strategies are designed to support long-term production. These assessments are generally performed during the reconnaissance and exploration phases before drilling, where data are synthesized to identify potential heat sources and host reservoirs, which are later confirmed through exploratory drilling at both shallow and deep levels.Geochemical characteristicsGeothermal systems exhibit rock-water interactions at moderate to high temperatures, with noticeable effects on the Earth‚Äôs surface. These interactions are often reflected in the chemical composition of spring water, making it a valuable indicator for studying geothermal systems. The water from Badrinath geothermal spring is mildly neutral, with a pH of 7 to 7.2. At 25¬†¬∞C, its enormous specific conductivity is 2690 micromhos/cm, while the total dissolved solids (TDS) content is 1910¬†mg/L. This geochemical characteristic suggests its deep circulation has a meteoric origin19. The surface temperature of the geothermal spring water is recorded at 55.5¬∞C19,37,49. The concentrations of various constituents (in mg/L) are detailed in Table 1.Table 1 The concentration of chemical constituents in the geothermal water of Badrinath19,37.Full size tableThe volumetric ‚Äò‚Äòheat in place‚Äô‚Äô method for geothermal resourceEvaluating geothermal resources requires analyzing each area‚Äôs location, size, and geological characteristics. This information is crucial for estimating the accessible resource base, the thermal energy stored in the reservoir, and the recoverable thermal energy. The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) volumetric ‚Äúheat in place‚Äù method is the most effective way to assess the energy potential of geothermal reservoirs. This reliable approach highlights the substantial resources available for sustainable energy production, underscoring the importance of geothermal energy in renewable solutions50. This study used the volume method to determine the stored energy and produced heat energy of a low-temperature geothermal reservoir in Badrinath. Microsoft Excel was utilized to conduct Monte Carlo simulation studies.The volume method is a highly effective strategy for calculating the thermal energy contained within a specific volume of rock and water, enabling a robust estimation of energy recovery potential. This method accurately determines the thermal energy in the ground by multiplying the volume of a geothermal reservoir by its mean temperature, porosity, and the specific heats of both rock and water. Alternatively, a more straightforward calculation can be employed using the volume, temperature, and an assumed volumetric specific heat51,52.While assessing recoverable thermal energy introduces more complexity, requiring an in-depth understanding of critical reservoir properties such as permeability, this challenge is well worth overcoming. In many cases, the recovery factor can only be approximated53, but the insights gained are invaluable. Notably, the volume method has proven highly effective in estimating thermal energy from low-temperature geothermal fields, underscoring its essential role in advancing sustainable energy solutions35.The volumetric method enhances this by combining MCS with the reservoir volume method24,33,34,35,36. Here, the volumetric method is adopted to estimate the geothermal power potential. The governing equations for total energy E in a geothermal system are given by:$${E}_{res} ={E}_{rock} + {E}_{fluid}$$
                    (1)
                $${E}_{rock }={V(1-\varnothing )}_{{\rho }_{rock} }\times {C}_{rock}\times \left({T}_{res }-{T}_{reference}\right)$$
                    (2)
                $${E}_{fluid }={(V\times \varnothing )}_{{\rho }_{fluid} }\times {C}_{fluid}\times \left({T}_{res }-{T}_{reference}\right)$$
                    (3)
                or$${E}_{fluid }={(V\times \varnothing )}_{{\rho }_{fluid} }\times \left({T}_{res }-{T}_{reference}\right)$$
                    (4)
                where.\({E}_{res}\) = Total energy in the reservoir (J);\({E}_{rock}\) = Energy in the reservoir rock (J);\({E}_{fluid}\) = Energy in the reservoir fluid (J);\({T}_{res}\) = Reservoir temperature (¬∞C);\({T}_{reference}\) = Reference temperature (¬∞C);V‚Äâ=‚ÄâReservoir volume calculated (m3);√ò‚Äâ=‚Äâporosity (fraction);œπ‚Äâ=‚ÄâHeat capacity (J/kg¬∞C);Œ°‚Äâ=‚ÄâDensity (kg/m3);’∞‚Äâ=‚ÄâEnthalpy (J/kg).Total recoverable thermal energy is given by:$${E}_{recoverable }=A\times R\times {E}_{res}$$
                    (5)
                where A‚Äâ=‚ÄâAccessibility, and R‚Äâ=‚ÄâRecovery factor.Therefore, thermal power \({P}_{thermal},\) the electrical energy capacity \({E}_{e}\) and power capacity \({P}_{e}\) can be determined by using:$${P}_{thermal} = \frac{{E}_{recoverable}}{\Delta T}$$
                    (6)
                $${E}_{e}={\eta }_{e}\times {E}_{recoverable} \left(above reference temperature\right)$$
                    (7)
                $${P}_{e} =\frac{{E}_{e}}{\Delta T}$$
                    (8)
                where,$${P}_{thermal }=Thermal Power \left(W\right);$$$${P}_{electric }=Power capacity \left(W\right);$$$${E}_{e}=Electircal energy capacity;$$$${\eta }_{e }=Efficiency of the power plant;$$$${\Delta }_{t }=Utilization time period.$$Monte Carlo simulation (MCS)The MCS employs stochastic techniques to assess the impact of measurements and uncertainties on petrophysical results. This technique is preferred because it allows the interpretation model to be processed multiple times with randomly varied parameters. It is often used when the model is complex, nonlinear, or contains uncertain parameters. While the method incorporates various approaches, they generally follow a common pattern. MCS is reliable and widely adopted in geothermal resource assessment, power generation, and techno-economic evaluations. It relies on the reservoir volume method and iterative sampling of probability distributions (e.g., uniform, triangular, Gaussian, PERT). It helps to estimate the probability and cumulative distributions of geothermal resources, with P90, P50, and P10 values representing 90%, 50%, and 10% probability outcomes54,55.Key steps in (MCS) calculation
                  
                    Selection or development of a probability model based on statistical data, analogies, and theoretical considerations.
                  
                  
                    Generation of random numbers and their corresponding random variables.
                  
                  
                    Design and implementation of variance reduction techniques to improve computational efficiency.
                  
                Input parameters for MCSIn this study, the collected data comprise reservoir temperature, formation thickness, porosity, formation rock density, specific heat, and the specific heat of formation fluid. These parameters are characterized using either uniform or triangular probability distributions. For the triangular distribution, each parameter is defined by its minimum, most likely, and maximum values, which makes this distribution particularly suitable when available data are limited35,56. Accordingly, triangular distributions are employed for density, specific heat capacity of rock, geothermal manifestation area, reservoir temperature, project lifespan, and reservoir lithology thickness. Uniform distributions are assigned to rock porosity and recovery factor, whereas constant distributions are used for hot water‚Äôs specific heat capacity and density, conversion efficiency, accessibility, and reference temperature. The MCS assessed the geothermal resource and power potential over 25, 35, and 50¬†years. The MCS runs with at least 100,000 iterations in Microsoft Excel. A comprehensive summary of all input parameters19,37 is provided in Tables 2 and 3.Table 2 Details of resistivity data of Badrinath Geothermal field, Garhwal Himalaya.Full size tableTable 3 Details of input parameters for the Monte Carlo volumetric assessment for 25, 35, and 50¬†years.Full size tableReservoir area and thicknessThe data range of the reservoir area has been selected based on the surface manifestation of geothermal activity according to19,37. In the Badrinath area, the lower order resistivity zone, having a resistivity range of 60 to 250 Ohm-meter with thickness ranging from 20 to 250¬†m, is indicated. The lowest resistivity, 60 Ohm-m, is recorded nearest to the hot spring manifestation (Table 2). This conductive zone appears to be significant from the point of view of geothermal potential. This zone‚Äôs resistivity may be lowered because of the heating effect of the hot fluids or the saturation57. The active geothermal area spreads over‚Äâ~‚Äâ3 km2 (Fig.¬†1) between Bamni village (south of Badrinath) and Mana village (north of Badrinath Town).Reservoir and reference temperatureThe reservoir temperature was taken from the literature for this study, taken from19,37,49. The maximum temperature may be 150¬†¬∞C. Here, 130¬†¬∞C was considered the most likely temperature of the geothermal reservoir, and the reference temperature is adopted as 20¬†¬∞C for this case Table 3. The reference temperature for district heating in a geothermal field depends on the context (energy calculation, system design, or efficiency evaluation), but generally, it represents the baseline temperature relative to which useful heat is calculated. The reference temperature is usually the ambient or ground temperature of the area, or sometimes the return temperature of the district heating network.Rock density and specific heatThe rocks exposed near the spring are gneisses, with interbedded schist, calcshist, quartzite, and a patch of marble. The porosity, specific heat, and density data of rocks exposed in the area have been obtained from university laboratory analysis36. The specific heat of water at 150¬†¬∞C is 4180¬†J/kg ¬∞C. This value is constant (Table 3). Conversion efficiency and recovery factors were adopted from the literature58. Accessibility is constant for this study.PorosityThis parameter can only be accurately determined through comprehensive testing. Studies indicate that about 90% of thermal energy is stored in the rock, with only 10% in the fluid59,60. Consequently, many researchers overlook porosity when using the volumetric method61. In this study, we adopt a uniform distribution, setting the most probable value at 5%, as supported by research in La Palma62 and standard practices in geothermal heat storage evaluation60. The details of the porosity are given in Table 3.Fluid density and fluid specific heatThe density of geothermal fluid is incorporated into the volumetric method as a function of resource temperature, based on the correlation previously applied in similar studies56. The details of these parameters are provided in Table 3. The specific heat of water at 150¬†¬∞C is 4180¬†J/kg ¬∞C. This value is constant. Accessibility is constant for this study.Recovery factorThe geothermal recovery factor is the ratio of heat recovered at the wellhead to the heat stored in the reservoir. This value typically depends on several factors, including the permeability structure, the characteristics of the wells, and the reservoir‚Äôs thermal and hydraulic boundary conditions. As a result, the recovery factor is not an intrinsic property used in resource evaluation with the volumetric method; rather, it reflects the actual operational characteristics of a reservoir63.Currently, there is no information regarding the permeability characteristics of the potential resource, as there is no evidence of permeable reservoirs in the locations being studied19,37. A range of 0‚Äì0.20 is considered, including the null value for low productivity and uncertainties, with 0.20 being the maximum credible value from liquid-dominated reservoirs. Details are provided in Table 3.Conversion efficiency (CE)Conversion efficiency is significantly influenced by the selected power cycle, which is ultimately linked to the temperature of the geothermal source. Given the anticipated temperatures of the L1 and L2 reservoirs, binary plant technology emerges as the most suitable option for harnessing the geothermal resource Table 3. A common practice is establishing a constant efficiency value of 10% to 16%, based on prior technical experience62. Conversion efficiency and recovery factor adopted from58. The Badrinath geothermal field is a medium enthalpy area.Input parameters for the House heating systemHouse heating systems maintain indoor temperatures (18-23¬∞C) during winter. Basic methods use fireplaces or individual units powered by gas, kerosene, boilers, or electricity. Central systems circulate hot water or steam to radiators or floor heating. Electrical resistance heating and air-to-air heat pumps are standard. District heating connects multiple homes to a shared hot water supply64.Building heat loss calculationThe heat loss of a building is a function of the outdoor weather conditions and indoor temperature, as well as the construction of the building components (insulation). The heat is lost by transfer through the building surface and by the exchange of air between the heated space and the surroundings of the building65. Low outdoor temperature and high wind speed are the most important parameters contributing to high heat losses from buildings.The building heat loss can be calculated as66:$$Q={Q}_{t}+{Q}_{v}+{Q}_{i}$$
                    (9)
                where Q‚Äâ=‚ÄâOverall heat loss (W);Qt‚Äâ=‚ÄâHeat loss caused by transmission through walls, windows, doors, and floors (W).Qv‚Äâ=‚ÄâHeat loss because of ventilation (W);Qi‚Äâ=‚ÄâHeat loss caused by infiltration (W);Calculation of heat loss through walls, roof, and windowsThe outdoor temperature acts as a primary influencing factor for the weather. The heat loss through walls, roofs, and windows can be estimated by using the equation given below:$${Q}_{t}=AU \left({T}_{i}-{T}_{0}\right)$$

                    (14)
                Ri and R0 are thermal resistances at the inner and outer surfaces of the building.Heat loss by ventilation (without heat recovery)The heat loss because of ventilation without heat recovery can be defined as:$${Q}_{v}={C}_{p}\rho {q}_{v}({T}_{i}-{T}_{0})$$

The value is hard to predict and depends on several variables‚Äìwind speed, the difference between inside and outside temperatures, the quality of the building construction, etc. The heat loss triggered by infiltration can be calculated66:$${Q}_{i}={C}_{p}\rho nV({T}_{i}-{T}_{0})$$

In this secondary loop, heated water is circulated through the heating equipment in the buildings (radiators, floor heating).                 where.\({m}_{h}\)= Mass flow rates of geothermal water as a heat source(kg/s);\({C}_{p}\) = Specific heat capacity of water (J/kg¬∞C);\({T}_{h1}=\) Temperature of inlet geothermal water at the heat exchanger (¬∞C);\({T}_{h2}=\) Temperature of outlet geothermal water at the heat exchanger (¬∞C);U  \(=\)   Overall heat transfer coefficient of the heat exchanger (W/m2¬∞C);A‚Äâ=‚ÄâSurface area of the heat exchanger (m2);\({\Delta T}_{m}=\) Logarithmic mean temperature difference (¬∞C);Results and discussionGeothermal power potential of the Badrinath reservoirTo comprehensively assess the geothermal potential under the current scenario, 100,000 iterations of Monte Carlo simulations were performed. This extensive number of simulations captures the full range of possible outcomes, enabling the estimation of a plausible bandwidth of geothermal potential, including the most likely value. The input parameters listed in Table 3 were used in the Monte Carlo simulation, with the results presented in Table 4. According to the input parameters (Table 3), the volumetric assessment predicts a 90%, 50%, and 10% probability that the reservoir could produce maximum power for 25, 35, and 50¬†years, respectively, with different capacities. Results of the probability of the distribution of thermal power and electricity are given in Table 4.Table 4 Volumetric generation of electricity and thermal power production for (25, 35, and 50¬†years).Full size tableThermal and electrical power potentialA 25-year forecastThe relative and cumulative probabilities for electricity generation (P_electric) and thermal power (P_thermal) are presented in Fig.¬†2. The cumulative frequency distribution resembles a probability density function constructed by incrementally summing the relative frequency of each bin. The relative frequency of a value or bin is computed as a fraction or percentage of the total data points. Figures¬†2A and C illustrate the relative frequency distribution of maximum thermal power and electricity generation over 25¬†years. In contrast, Figs. 2B and D display the cumulative frequency distribution, calculated from the random variable‚Äôs maximum to the minimum value. The vertical axis in these plots represents the cumulative frequencies greater than or equal to specific values. Alternatively, a reverse plot could be generated, where the axis represents frequencies less than or equal to given values. By definition, the cumulative frequency at the maximum value is always 1; at the minimum, it is 0.Fig. 2Relative frequency plots of the volumetric reserves estimation of the Badrinath geothermal field for 25¬†years.Full size imageIn Figs. 2B and D, the probability of generating a minimum of 1.5 MWe and 18.0 MWt is 90% (proven reserves). The probability of achieving at least 2.1 MWe and 27.2 MWt is 50% (proven‚Äâ+‚Äâprobable reserves or most likely). Meanwhile, the probability of reaching 3.1 MWe and 39.5 MWt is 10% (proven‚Äâ+‚Äâprobable‚Äâ+‚Äâpossible reserves or maximum potential). These findings suggest that the Badrinath geothermal field could initially support a 1.5 MWe power plant for 25¬†years based on surface manifestations without drilling.A 35-year forecastFigure¬†3 presents the relative and cumulative probabilities of P_electric and P_thermal over a 35-year forecast. Volumetric analysis estimates 90%, 50%, and 10% probabilities of sustaining minimum power generation over time. Table 4 details probability distributions for P_electric and P_thermal, while Figs. 4A‚ÄìD shows cumulative curves resembling a probability density function. Surface data suggest the Badrinath field could initially support a 0.7 MWe plant for 50¬†years.Fig. 4Relative frequency plots of volumetric reserve estimates for the Badrinath field over 50¬†years.Full size imageSensitivity analysis of MCS inputAmong the key input parameters in our Monte Carlo simulations, the reservoir‚Äôs volume, temperature, and recovery factor are the most uncertain variables. Their significant influence on the simulated capacity output is reflected in the thermal power, electrical energy capacity, and power capacity described in Eqs.¬†(1, 3, 6, 7) and the minimum‚Äìmaximum range in Table 3. While we established triangular distributions for the Badrinath reservoir based on credible data, variations in the mode (the most likely value) can significantly affect the final results. To illustrate this, we conducted additional Monte Carlo iterations, adjusting each zone‚Äôs most likely recovery factor and volume. In this analysis, we treated volume as an independent variable rather than deriving it from reservoir area and thickness. The most likely recovery factor was adjusted from 0.1 to 0.2, while the minimum and maximum values for the triangular and uniform distributions were kept constant per Table 3. All other distributions remained unchanged, highlighting the critical importance of precise input parameters for reliable simulation outcomes.District heating potential of the Badrinath geothermal fieldThis study evaluates the geothermal potential of the Badrinath field using the volumetric method and Monte Carlo simulation to determine its feasibility for space heating in the Garhwal region of the northwest Himalaya. Geothermal water and steam are sustainable energy sources for electricity generation and direct use. Electricity generation utilizes geothermal heat (130¬†¬∞C to 300¬†¬∞C) to produce mechanical energy, achieving 10% to 30% efficiencies. Direct uses, such as space heating, attain 50% to 80% of thermal efficiencies68. Co-generation systems optimize energy use by integrating both methods. District heating systems, effective in cold regions, offer cost-efficient heating solutions. This study also assesses the potential for geothermal house heating in Badrinath, comparing it to successful European models, particularly from Iceland. The volumetric assessment shows promising potential, with estimates indicating the field could generate at least 3 MWe of electricity and 39 MWt of thermal power upon successful drilling. This makes it suitable for a geothermal heating system at a government guesthouse managed by the Garhwal Mandal Vikas Nigam in Badrinath town. The geothermal water‚Äôs chemical composition, primarily Na‚ÄìHCO‚ÇÉ, is detailed in Table 1.Design and heating load assessment of the siteThe government guesthouse is the primary commercial building in Badrinath town, comprising 20 rooms and a dormitory with over 300 beds. It is located 300¬†m from the geothermal resource, with an aerial distance of 200¬†m from the spring. The guesthouse spans 1000 m2 (50‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ20¬†m) with a volume of 8000 m3 (50‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ20‚Äâ√ó‚Äâ8¬†m). The heat demand of the building is primarily influenced by outdoor temperature, though factors like wind speed and solar radiation also play a role. Input parameters indicate that the maximum outdoor temperature reaches 15¬†¬∞C (the required room temperature for human comfort) for only one month annually.In contrast, sub-zero temperatures persist for over six months, necessitating space heating. Studies estimate the Badrinath geothermal reservoir temperature between 130 and 150¬†¬∞C. Heat will be supplied using wall-mounted steel radiators, though their quantity is yet to be determined. Return water temperature sensors will regulate the radiator flow rate. The system will include steel pipes (1 or 1.5 inches in diameter) for internal circulation and pre-insulated plastic pipes (PEX, 52¬†mm diameter, 300¬†m long) for outdoor installation. The heating system is designed for a peak load of 320 kWt.The town has a stable electricity supply, minimizing the risk of power failure affecting pump operation. To enhance reliability, 1¬†MW solar power units will be installed. Since the hot spring is at a lower elevation (5¬†m) than the guesthouse, pumping is required to transport the geothermal water. A schematic of the system is shown in Fig.¬†5, illustrating key components: hot springs, heat exchangers, pumps, transmission pipes, and radiators. The maximum discharge rate of the spring is 430 L per minute, with a natural outflow temperature of 55.5¬†¬∞C, currently used for tourism-related bathing. Chemical analysis of the geothermal water19 confirms its suitability for direct-use heating without scaling or corrosion risks in pipes or radiators. However, a heat exchanger system will be implemented to prevent freezing in outdoor pipes during low ambient temperatures. In case of pump failure, a closed-loop system will circulate freshwater mixed with 30% ethylene glycol antifreeze through the radiators. Direct through-flow of geothermal water would be more efficient if the spring were higher, but this is not the case. Among various heat exchanger types, the brazed plate heat exchanger is preferred because of:Fig. 5Proposed schematic diagram for space heating for the government guesthouse.Full size image(i) Compact design with a high power-to-volume ratio (m3/kW); (ii) Enhanced heat transfer efficiency because of high turbulence (even at Reynolds numbers as low as 10‚Äì400), which also prevents fouling; (iii) Lightweight and easy handling compared to other systems. A similar geothermal heating system was successfully implemented at Chumathang, Ladakh, in 2014, where a small-scale heating system was deployed68. The heat exchanger will be housed in a small hut near the spring in Badrinath. Hot-dip galvanized steel pipes will carry water to the 370 W self-priming electric pump, circulating water through the heat exchanger. The winter design conditions are 55.5¬†¬∞C inlet and 30¬†¬∞C outlet temperatures, with the outlet water discharged into the natural runoff. Detailed heat loss and heat exchange calculations are provided in the supplementary material (Appendix 1 from Tables 5‚Äì11).ConclusionsThis paper presents the first evaluation of geothermal resources and power potential estimation of the Badrinath geothermal field. Based on the available published geological and geophysical data, the volumetric heat in place method combined with the Monte Carlo simulation approach was applied in the most promising zones identified in the literature of India. Geo-thermometric analysis indicates subsurface reservoir temperatures between 100 and 140¬†¬∞C, confirming the field‚Äôs suitability for low-temperature geothermal development. Using the volumetric method combined with Monte Carlo simulations to account for uncertainties, the study estimated power potential under 25, 35, and 50-year utilization scenarios. For 25¬†years, thermal power output (MWt) was estimated at P10: 39.5, P50: 27.3, and P90: 18.0, with corresponding electric power output (MWe) of 3.2, 2.2, and 1.4.Badrinath geothermal field could initially support a 1.04 MWe plant for 35¬†years. For 50¬†years, thermal output was 19.7, 13.7, and 9.0 MWt, with electric output at 1.6, 1.1, and 0.7 MWe. These results demonstrate that the available geothermal resource can provide a consistent and sustainable source of electricity and heating for Badrinath, significantly reducing reliance on fossil fuels. However, the current geothermal spring discharge is adequate to meet the heating needs of the guesthouse. Overall, this study confirms that the geothermal resource in the Garhwal Himalaya presents a viable and sustainable energy solution for high-altitude, remote regions.Despite considerable geological uncertainties, the techno-economic analysis strongly demonstrates that geothermal energy is a reliable, cost-effective, and cost-competitive solution. It is crucial in propelling India toward its ambitious carbon‚Äìneutral and green energy goals.

items.title: Enhancing hydropower resilience through dynamic rule curve modifications under climate change in the Sunkoshi multipurpose scheme, Nepal
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 09 October 2025

Enhancing hydropower resilience through dynamic rule curve modifications under climate change in the Sunkoshi multipurpose scheme, Nepal
                    Ram Krishna Regmi1, Arish Shrestha1, Vishan Dahal1 & ‚Ä¶Subash Kunwar1¬†Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume¬†15, Article¬†number:¬†35317 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate changeHydrology

AbstractAmid Nepal‚Äôs expanding hydropower sector, the Sunkoshi Multipurpose Scheme stands as a pivotal inter-basin transfer project. As the country seeks to maximize its abundant water resources, strengthening hydropower resilience against the inevitable impacts of climate change is imperative for ensuring long-term energy sustainability. This study conducts a comprehensive assessment of climate change impacts on the Sunkoshi River Basin and proposes an adaptive management strategy through dynamic rule curve modifications, optimizing reservoir operations in response to projected shifts in water availability across different time horizons of the 21st century. Seven bias-corrected General Circulation Models (GCMs) (ACCESS-CM2, BCC-CSM2-MR, CanESM5, EC-Earth3, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, MPI-ESM1-2-LR, and NorESM2-MM) were adopted for the projection of climate variables under Shared Socio-Economic Pathways (SSP)245 and SSP585 scenarios which were further utilized for the projection of future discharge in the Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT). The anticipated inflow data served as input to the Hydraulic Engineering Center- Reservoir System Simulation (HEC-ResSim) software to simulate the reservoir operation and propose modified rule curves for Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3, and Dudhkoshi hydropower projects for the time frame of 2030s, 2060s, and 2080s. Six different rule curves were proposed and average yearly energy generations were maximized ranging from 25.5%, 61.07%, 71.26%, and 10.50% for Sunkoshi No.3, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.1, and Dudhkoshi power plants respectively. These results could be helpful for long-term planning, urging policymakers to integrate dynamic rule curve modifications in the broader context of sustainable energy production and climate change adaptation.

IntroductionAmong the numerous challenges confronting the 21st century, climate change stands as one of the most pressing issues, primarily driven by anthropogenic activities1. Our globe has witnessed enormous changes over the past few decades through evidence such as rising global temperatures, extreme rainfall patterns, extreme weather events, and numerous impacts on the life that resides on this planet including humans2. Beyond climate variability that occurs naturally, human-induced climate variation has had extensive negative effects on nature and people, including more frequent and powerful extreme events3. The possible consequences of climate change will be more visible in the Himalayan region, where glacier melt and snowmelt dominate flow4. Snowmelt contributes about 20% of annual stream flow in the Hindu Kush-Himalayan area, with a maximum contribution of \(\:>\)65% in the Indus watershed5. In the Sunkoshi basin, snowmelt contributes 6.1% and glacier runoff 10.5% of the total runoff, with snowmelt and baseflow together providing over 81.6% during the high crop water demand pre-monsoon period, while glacier runoff peaks at 11.5% from July to September6. Global warming intensifies the hydrological cycle, resulting in an accelerated rate of glacier and snowmelt in cryospheric-dominated basins. This process subsequently enhances downstream runoff, influencing water availability and hydrological regimes. This variability has consequences for both reservoir and Run off River (RoR) hydropower plants, the latter being more sensitive as the availability of flow varies with time as a result of climate change7.In 2022, global installed hydropower capacity increased by 26 GW to 1360 GW8. According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), hydropower will provide around 15% of global electricity generation in 2023‚Äì2030, with an average annual generation growth rate of close to 4%9. Also, Nepal‚Äôs hydroelectric generation increased significantly in FY2023, adding 500¬†MW for the second year in a row10. Nepal generated 1,050¬†MW of hydropower till 2012, and by 2023, this capacity had expanded to 2,800¬†MW, demonstrating remarkable development11. Developing a portion of Nepal‚Äôs hydropower potential has been shown to result in robust economic growth, significantly reducing poverty in the process12. Despite its potential benefits, Nepal‚Äôs hydroelectric growth is sensitive to climate change, which may have economic consequences13. The direct cost associated with the current climate variability and extreme events has been estimated to be equivalent to 1.5‚Äì2% of the current GDP/year and will be much higher in extreme years anticipated to rise by 5% or more which is higher as per the international levels14. So, the economic advancement and the overall prosperity of a nation directly or indirectly depend on how the natural resources, notably water, within the specific context of countries like Nepal are managed by their planners and policymakers through strategic decisions to ensure sustainable utilization of these crucial resources. Also, climate change may modify past hydrological patterns, leading to spatial and temporal variability in water flowing through rivers15. The predictability of water availability is hindered by this unpredictability, making it perplexing to optimize hydropower generation schedules. In the pursuit of optimizing energy generation, an assessment of the impacts due to climate variability and fluctuation in the river discharge becomes crucial.Nepal‚Äôs complex geology and varied topography render it highly vulnerable to climate change, particularly in terms of glacial dynamics and shifting precipitation patterns. These factors play a critical role in regulating river discharge, with profound implications for hydropower generation, agricultural productivity, and rural livelihoods16. Numerous researches have been conducted in several major river basins of Nepal by a number of researchers considering different General Circulation models (GCMs) developed by Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP) and considering various emission scenarios. By the end of the century, Nepal‚Äôs average surface temperature is projected to increase by approximately 5.8¬†¬∞C17. In the mid-term, temperature rises are expected to range between 0.9¬†¬∞C and 1.1¬†¬∞C, while long-term projections indicate an increase of 1.3¬†¬∞C to 1.8¬†¬∞C18. As a result of the temperature rise, the snowcaps are likely to melt more quickly ultimately leading to extreme events such as pluvial floods and glacier lake outburst flooding, eventually causing damage to hydraulic structures that are intended to be constructed in the river. According to a study carried out for the West Seti River basin of Nepal, water yield was likely to escalate as a consequence of an upsurge in precipitation, with high flows anticipated to increase and conversely, low flows projected to decrease19. Similarly, fluctuations in the flow from a seasonal point of view are also vital. Despite the uncertainty and unpredictability associated with the assessment of climate variability, pre-monsoon and monsoon seasons are more likely to experience an upsurge, particularly during the monsoon season, which could cause widespread damage to infrastructure, livelihoods, and settlements in the future20. Also, future projections based on Regional Climate Models (RCMs) suggest a decrease of over 30% in monthly flow during drier months and an increase of more than 25% during high flow months compared to baseline values for the Koshi River Basin21. The synergistic effect of higher temperatures and increased precipitation leads to a 50% rise in discharge at the Kaligandaki River basin outlet, largely attributed to a projected 90% increase in snowmelt by the 2090s22. Climate-induced changes in temperature and precipitation in the Karnali River Basin are projected to increase future water availability, with annual discharge expected to rise by 6.4‚Äì8.4% under RCP 4.5 and by 5.1‚Äì10.9% under RCP 8.5 by 2040‚Äì2099, especially during pre-monsoon and monsoon seasons, likely intensifying later in the century23.Numerous studies that have been conducted for the comprehensive evaluation of climate change impact significantly in the context of river basins in Nepal were executed using the GCMs that were developed by CMIP5 and the Representative Concentration Pathways scenarios. Recently a new collection of scenarios has been created for ScenarioMIP, the section of the global CMIP6 of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP) that includes scenario runs for the twenty-first century and these scenarios are known as Shared Socio-economic Pathways (SSP). This study attempts to consider the new SSP scenarios for the study, which will help visualize the climate change variations based on both socioeconomic as well as Greenhouse Gas (GHG) concentrations. High-resolution CMIP6 models provide improved simulations of precipitation patterns and temperature variability, capturing regional climate phenomena more accurately24. Additionally, updated parameterizations of physical processes, including cloud microphysics, aerosols, and land-surface interactions like vegetation dynamics and soil moisture, enhance the models‚Äô ability to represent land-atmosphere interactions effectively25. While the models used in this study‚ÄîGCMs, Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT), and Hydrologic Engineering Center‚Äôs Reservoir System Simulation (HEC-ResSim)‚Äîare widely applied in hydrological and climate change research, this study provides a unique contribution by integrating these tools in a novel way to address the challenges of climate change impacts on hydropower operations in Nepal. The SWAT model is widely used globally for hydrological studies due to its ability to simulate comprehensive processes and its user-friendly interface, making it ideal for diverse applications26. Additionally, the SWAT-CUP program‚Äôs semi-automated technique (SUFI-2) can assist users in performing more thorough sensitivity and uncertainty analysis27. HEC-ResSim is a software developed by the US Army Corps of Engineers, Hydrological Engineering Center (HEC) with US Federal Government resources28. HEC-ResSim is a multi-reservoir simulation model, effectively models water resource systems29. The SWAT-HEC-ResSim-GA framework underpins resilient reservoir management by enhancing understanding of complex systems and enabling uncertainty assessment from various sources across decision-making phases, fostering informed and adaptive water resource planning and operation30. Khatri et al. (2024)31 optimizes the reservoir operation in the Tamor basin storage project strategies using particle-swarm optimization, adapting to altered streamflow, mitigating pre-monsoon flow deficits, and enhancing annual energy generation and downstream dry-season flows. Previous studies have primarily focused on evaluating alterations in discharge and power generation within hydropower projects, neglecting to propose effective adaptation strategies in response to climate change. For instance, Pradhan et al. (2021)17 mainly focus on evaluation of CMIP5 GCMs for precipitation and temperature simulations in the Koshi River Basin. Budhathoki et al. (2021)19 assessed changes in water balance and hydrological extremes in the West Seti Basin but provided limited adaptation insights, and Dahal et al. (2020)23 modeled climate change impacts on water availability in the Karnali Basin. Operational strategies for hydropower adaptation are further needed. Consequently, it is imperative to develop an adaptation strategy, especially for complex projects like the Sunkoshi multipurpose project, which encompasses the construction of four distinct reservoir-type projects in series.This study aims to examine the alterations in the climate variables using seven GCMs developed by CMIP6 under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios. The impact of these alterations in the hydrological regime of the Sunkoshi River basin will be evaluated by examining the alterations in the flow and ultimately to the hydropower generations of four planned reservoir-type projects, namely Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3 and Dudhkoshi. Furthermore, this study seeks to propose dynamic rule curves for cascading reservoirs in the Sunkoshi Basin to ensure sustainable and efficient hydropower generation. Unlike previous studies that primarily assessed the impacts of climate change on hydropower without proposing adaptive strategies, this study integrates dynamic rule curve modifications using climate projections and reservoir operation simulations. By iteratively adjusting reservoir levels based on projected flow changes, this study bridges the gap between hydrological modeling and real-time hydropower management, offering a novel operational framework for climate adaptation.Materials and methodsStudy areaThe Sunkoshi River Basin is a transboundary basin shared by Tibet (China) and Nepal, encompassing the catchment areas of key tributaries, including Bhote Koshi, Indravati, Tamakoshi, Likhu, and Dudhkoshi. Originating from the Zhangzangbo Glacier in Tibet32, the Sunkoshi River flows into Nepal, where the Indravati River joins it near Dolaghat. The river then meanders eastward through the valley formed by the Mahabharat Range and the Himalayas32. At Tribenighat, the Sunkoshi converges with the Tamur and Arun rivers to form the Saptakoshi. The basin extends from 85¬∞23‚Äô13.2‚Äô‚Äô E to 87¬∞9‚Äô25.2‚Äô‚Äô E longitude and 28¬∞31‚Äô26.4‚Äô‚Äô N to 26¬∞34‚Äô58.8‚Äô‚Äô N latitude, with elevation ranging from 111 to 8777 masl with catchment area of approximately 18,140 km2. This study deals with the four proposed Storage type projects: Sunkoshi No.3, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.1, and Dudhkoshi Hydropower projects. Figure¬†1 shows the study area map, highlighting the location of these four storage-type projects planned to be constructed in the Sunkoshi River basin. Table¬†1 provides a summary of the salient features of these four reservoir-type projects. Additionally, the basin includes two inter-basin transfer initiatives: the Sunkoshi Marin Diversion Multipurpose Project (SMDMP) and the Sunkoshi Kamala Diversion Multipurpose Project (SKDMP).Fig. 1Study Area Map showing Sunkoshi River Basin, Nepal.Full size imageTable 1 Salient features of storage type projects proposed by JICA33,34.Full size tableDataHydro-meteorological and temperature dataDaily hydrological data from 1990 to 2014 AD of stations located at Pachuwarghat, Rabuwa bazar, and Hampachuwar and meteorological data for the same period from 13 stations within the basin were collected from the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM), Nepal. However, most of these stations were located in lower-elevation regions, necessitating the integration of data from higher-altitude areas for a more comprehensive representation. To address this limitation, precipitation data from the Asian Precipitation‚ÄìHighly-Resolved Observational Data Integration Towards Evaluation of Extreme Events (APHRODITE) database were incorporated. The reliability of APHRODITE‚Äôs daily precipitation estimates over Nepal was rigorously evaluated through comparative analysis with ground-based gauge observations35. Similarly, daily maximum and minimum temperature data of three stations: Dhulikhel, Jiri, and Okhaldhunga were collected and further used in the analysis.Digital Elevation Model (DEM), Land use and Land cover (LULC), and Soil data for hydrological modelingSWAT model requires DEM, LULC map, and Soil map for the preparation of a hydrological model7. NASA Digital Elevation Model (NASADEM) was downloaded from NASA‚Äôs official website and used for the watershed delineation. The LULC map for the Hindu Kush Himalayan (HKH) region as of 2010 AD was acquired from the International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD) website with an equivalent scale of 1:50,000. The soil Map for the basin was downloaded from the official website of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) for the United Nations. These maps were processed and clipped to the basin area using ArcGIS v.10.8.2 software. The resulting DEM, LULC, and soil maps are shown in Fig.¬†2.Fig. 2a DEM, b LULC, c Soil Map for the Sunkoshi River basin.Full size imageProjected climate dataIn this study, seven bias-corrected datasets from CMIP6-GCMs for the historic (1951‚Äì2014) and projected (2015‚Äì2100) climates for the two scenarios (SSP245, SSP585) were used. Mishra et al. (2020) have developed the daily bias-corrected data of precipitation, maximum and minimum temperature at 0.25¬∞ spatial resolution for South Asia and 18 river basins located in the Indian sub-continent36. SSP245 considers a middle of the road pathway which depicts an intermediate scenario with moderate challenges to mitigation and adaptation, population growth, substantial divergence in income trends among nations, and a level of cooperation between states, while SSP585 illustrates a high-emission, fossil-fuel-driven future with significant challenges. Together, these scenarios encompass a spectrum from low-mid to high emissions, allowing researchers to assess various climate impacts and uncertainties effectively37 and hence were selected for this study. The GCMs used in the research include ACCESS-CM2, BCC-CSM2-MR, CanESM5, EC-Earth3, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, MPI-ESM1-2-LR, and NorESM2-MM. The selection of GCMs for this study was based on multiple criteria to ensure robust climate projections over the Sunkoshi River basin. The chosen seven GCMs mentioned above were selected based on the following factors:
                
                  i)
                  
                    Performance in South Asia and the Himalayan Region: These models have been widely used in climate impact studies due to their ability to simulate monsoon variability and high-altitude climate processes, both of which are critical for hydropower assessment in Nepal.
                  
                
                
                  ii)
                  
                    Bias-Corrected Data Availability: The selected GCMs have high-resolution, bias-corrected datasets for South Asia36, which enhances their applicability for hydrological modeling.
                  
                
                
                  iii)
                  
                    Diversity in Model Structures and Origins: The selected models represent different modeling institutions and methodologies, reducing dependency on a single climate modeling framework and capturing a broader range of possible climate futures.
                  
                
                
                  iv)
                  
                    Use in Previous Studies: These GCMs have been utilized in prior hydrological and climate studies in Nepal and the South Asian region, ensuring their reliability in similar applications.
                  
                
                
                  v)
                  
                    Ensemble Approach for Uncertainty Reduction: Since individual GCMs may contain biases or uncertainties, using multiple models helps provide a more representative range of future climate conditions, minimizing the influence of outliers.
                  
                
              Reservoir system dataPhysical and operation data for the simulation of reservoir operation are required as an input in the HEC-ResSim38 that includes Elevation-Area-Volume (E-A-V) data, routing parameters, dam and spillway data, and information on evaporation and seepage losses. These datasets were acquired from reports prepared by the Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA) and prior studies carried out for these hydropower projects33,34.MethodologyThe prime focus of this study is to study the variations in precipitation, temperature, and discharge patterns across the past, present, and future time series and present a strategy for the operation of four substantial planned hydropower reservoirs in the Sunkoshi river basin that adapts to the varying climatic and flow patterns. To accomplish the objective of this study, the adopted methodology involved a series of stepwise sub procedures. These procedures incorporated the future climate projection employing a bias correction method, the development of a hydrological model in ArcSWAT 10.8, and finally the simulation of reservoir operation through HEC-ResSim 3.3 software. Figure¬†3 represents the adopted methodological framework.Projection of future climate scenariosThe future climate variables, specifically precipitation and temperature, were forecasted using downscaled GCMs developed by Mishra et al. (2020)36. The selected seven GCMs precipitation and temperature data underwent downscaling at local station levels, considering two distinct scenarios, SSP245 and SSP585. Since, the GCMs models possess higher resolutions, they tend to fail to imitate climate data at the basin scale due to biasness39. Therefore, bias correction is necessary to align the simulated data more closely with observed conditions before conducting impact assessments40.Temperature and precipitation simulations frequently exhibit significant biases due to systematic model errors or discretization and spatial averaging within grid cells, limiting the use of simulated climate data as direct input data for hydrological models40. To minimize the dissimilarity between observed and simulated quantities on a daily time step, bias correction processes were employed such that the model reflects the real-time phenomenon pretty well41. For this study, CMhyd software was employed for bias correction and downscaling the regional climate model to the local scale. CMhyd identifies biases between observed and simulated historical climate data and applies the same correction factors to future projections to ensure compatibility with hydrological models41. Among the various correction methods available for bias correction, Linear scaling (Multiplicative) and Linear scaling (Additive) were employed for precipitation and temperature variables respectively. The linear scaling method is comparatively simple for application and has almost similar accuracy as compared to the complex ones39. Furthermore, the effectiveness of the bias correction in these models was assessed by comparing the observed DHM data and the bias-corrected data through three statistical indices: Nash‚ÄìSutcliffe simulation efficiency (NSE), percentage bias (PBIAS), and coefficient of determination (R2) for three climate variables: Precipitation, Maximum temperature, and Minimum temperature, which are illustrated in Supplementary Table S.1- S.6 and Figure S.1-S.3.This study used the Multiple Model Ensemble approach for future climate projections. Preferably, utilizing the average of an ensemble of GCMs cancels out individual model errors and reduces ensemble uncertainty as more models are utilized42. The arithmetic ensemble mean is widely used in research, as it provides a better representation of observed data by reducing biases and errors present in any single model43. The ensemble approach reduces biases from individual models and provides a probabilistic range of future climate conditions.Fig. 3Methodological Flowchart.Full size imageHydrological modeling of watershed in SWATThe current study utilized the SWAT software as a foundational tool to simulate river discharge for historical and upcoming periods in the Sunkoshi River basin under various climate change scenarios. The model setup was conducted using ArcSWAT v.2018, which operates as a semi-distributed model. For setting up a watershed model, the first step involved dividing the watershed into sub-basins, which are delineated based on surface topography, ensuring that all regions within a sub-basin flow to its designated outflow44. After the sub-basin delineation, the Hydrological response unit (HRU) was defined. LULC, soil, and slope data were entered and reclassified for the development of HRUs. The completed model setup resulted in 46 sub-basins and 195 HRUs. The weather files were then loaded into the SWAT model after being updated in the SWAT database by creating a weather generator file. Climate data were also entered into the model, and the simulation was run on a daily time step for 25 years (1990‚Äì2014) with a 3-year warmup period (1990‚Äì1992). The simulation was followed by sensitivity analysis. Sensitivity analysis is a crucial aspect of developing hydrological models like the SWAT45. It involves assessing the influence of input parameters on model outputs. These analyses aid in understanding parameter behavior, optimizing model performance, and supporting robust decision-making in watershed management.Evaluation of hydrological modelThe model‚Äôs output precision is highly related to how effectively its parameters are calibrated, with a strong link to the observed data used during the calibration and validation stages. In this study, multi-station calibration and validation were employed at hydrological stations, namely Station 630, Station 670, and Station 681. The initial three years (1990‚Äì1992) were used for the warm-up period. Similarly, the model was calibrated between 1993 and 2002 whereas, the validation period was between 2003 and 2014. The performance of the model was evaluated based on three statistical parameters: R2, NSE, and PBIAS. Model simulation can be considered satisfactory if NSE‚Äâ>‚Äâ0.50 and if PBIAS<\(\:\pm\:25\)\(\:\:\left[46\right]\). Also, if R2\(\:>\)0.5 model is considered acceptable47.After the calibration and validation processes, the calibrated parameters obtained were incorporated into the SWAT model for the development of a calibrated hydrological model. Subsequently, projected climate scenario data for the future were integrated into the model. The simulation was executed using a daily time step for a time period of 2018 to 2100. A preliminary warm-up phase spanning three years (2015 to 2017) was undertaken before the main simulation to ensure model stability. The principal aim of this simulation was to forecast the forthcoming discharge patterns.Simulation of reservoir operation in HEC-ResSimSimulation of reservoir operation under future climate scenarios was conducted using HEC-ResSim v. 3.3 software. The user interface of HEC-ResSim allows the development of a model in three stages, which include Watershed Setup, Reservoir Network, and Simulation. In the watershed setup module, the stream alignment of the Sunkoshi River basin was established by importing the shapefile of the river network. Computation points were then added to the alignment and the project elements which include the four reservoir projects and diversions. In the reservoir network module, the model schematic and its elements that include reservoirs, routing reaches, junction diversions, diverted outlets, and all their physical and operational data were defined. Operational data for the reservoirs were entered into the model, which incorporated four major operational zones: Flood Control, Conservation, Inactive, and Buffer zones. The rule curve that determines the reservoir pool elevation in different months of the year is defined as a buffer zone. Simulations were performed for a 22-year baseline period (1993‚Äì2014) using daily flow data and for two future climate scenarios‚ÄîSSP245 and SSP585‚Äîover the period 2018‚Äì2100. Figure¬†4 represents the reservoir network model setup that was developed for the climate change impact analysis.Fig. 4Reservoir Model Setup developed in HEC-ResSim v. 3.3.Full size imageModification of reservoir rule curve in response to climate changeOptimal rule curves serve as essential guidelines in reservoir operations48. Given the projected change in future discharge, this study adopted a dynamic rule curve modification approach, which refers to the adaptive and time-sensitive updating of reservoir operation rules to align with evolving climate conditions. Unlike static rule curves that are fixed based on historical data, dynamic rule curves are re-optimized for each future period (2030s, 2060s, and 2080s) under different emission scenarios (SSP245 and SSP585). This allows for flexible and scenario-specific reservoir operations, enabling better energy generation outcomes and greater system resilience to climate change.Results and discussionAnalysis of future climate projectionsIn this study, an ensemble of seven GCM projections was utilized to project future climate variables for each station up to 2100 AD for two scenarios SSP245 and SSP585. Each projection was then looked out for three future timeframes: 2030s (2015‚Äì2039), 2060s (2040‚Äì2064) and 2080s (2065‚Äì2089). Climate analysis was done on a yearly and seasonal basis (Pre-monsoon, Monsoon, post-monsoon, and Winter) in all three futures for each station and all climate variables.Figure 5 illustrates the percentage rise in monthly precipitations across different time spans under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios. Notably, the projected changes exhibit irregular trends. In the 2030s, a substantial increase in precipitation is observed in September, reaching 33.81% under SSP245 and 36.51% under SSP585, while notable decreases occur in January, by 10.97% and 21.04%, respectively. Similarly, during 2060s large increase in precipitation can be seen in December by 37.01% and in May by 41.69% under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios respectively. In the 2080s, may shows the highest increase-34.79% under SSP245 and 50.40% under SSP585-whereas January records the most pronounced decrease, with 36.02% under SSP245 and 33.75% under SSP585. From a seasonal perspective, Precipitation increases during the pre-monsoon, monsoon, and post-monsoon seasons are projected under both scenarios, with larger changes under SSP585 in the 2080s. In contrast, winter precipitation is projected to decline consistently, particularly in January and February. SSP585 generally shows greater variability and extremes in precipitation compared to SSP245, reflecting its more severe emission scenario. These findings align with previous studies that report increasing pre-monsoon precipitation across the lowlands and high mountains of central Nepal, rising monsoonal precipitation in the middle mountains of the west and high hills of central Nepal, and a consistent decline in winter precipitation49.Fig. 5Change in monthly precipitation amount for the projected periods and scenarios (a) SSP245 and (b) SSP585.Full size imageThe percentage change in average monthly maximum temperature in different time periods under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios is depicted in Fig.¬†6. A warmup period is deemed necessary to stabilize the model48 so, the initial three years (1990‚Äì1992) were allocated as the warmup period. Calibration was carried out using Sequential Uncertainty Fitting Ver-2 (SUFI-2) as an optimization algorithm which is made available by SWAT-CUP software. Initially, a range of minimum and maximum values was assigned to each parameter and after running the simulation, SWAT-CUP generated the values that fitted the best for the model which were later used for developing a calibrated model in ArcSWAT. The model was run on daily time steps for all three hydrological stations. Simulations were carried out for 500‚Äì1000 iterations, and once satisfactory statistical indices were achieved, the model underwent a final phase of refinement with 2000 iterations.Additionally, global sensitivity analysis was performed in SWAT-CUP. The most sensitive parameter is based on the values of the t-stat and p-value. t-stat and p-value are used to identify each parameter‚Äôs relative significance. The t-stat is the ratio of the parameter coefficient to its standard error. A higher absolute t-stat value indicates a greater influence of the parameter on the model output, while a lower p-value (p‚Äâ‚â§‚Äâ0.05) suggests statistical significance27. During the 2060s, these increments become even greater, with Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3, and Dudhkoshi expected to yield 3427.12 GWh/yr, 3207.23 GWh/yr, 1864.51 GWh/yr, and 3192.60 GWh/yr, respectively.
